title: How to Clean Metal

steps.headline: Clean aluminum with an acid, like lemon or vinegar.
steps.description: Wash the pot or pan with warm, soapy water. Rinse it out, then fill it up with clean water, 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of lemon juice or white vinegar, and boil the water for 15 minutes. Carefully dump out the water after 15 minutes and dry the item off thoroughly. To clean off burned-on food, pour some water into the soiled pot or pan and boil it on a burner for 5 minutes; after that, you can scrape away the burnt-on food with a rubber spatula. To clean an aluminum surface with acid, cut a lemon in half, dip the exposed end in salt, then rub it over the aluminum surface. Wipe the surface down afterward with a damp cloth and then dry it off thoroughly. Avoid using steel wool or anything similar on your aluminum goods—you may be tempted to scour stuck on food, but doing so could permanently damage the item.

steps.headline: Keep your cast iron in perfect condition with cooking oil.
steps.description: Run your dirty cast iron pot or pan under warm water and use a plastic scrubber to clean off leftover bits of food. Blot it dry with paper towel, then pour a little bit of olive oil onto a dry paper towel and lightly coat the interior of the pot or pan with cooking oil. Store your cast iron items in a cool place that doesn’t come into contact with any moisture. Never put your cast iron into the dishwasher or soak it in water for a long time (it’ll rust really quickly).

steps.headline: Polish brass with lemon and baking soda.
steps.description: Wipe down the brass item with a wet, soapy cloth. Squeeze the juice out of a cut lemon into a small bowl. Mix in about 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 grams) of baking soda until it combines with the juice to make a paste. Buff the brass with the paste using a clean, lint-free towel, rinse away the residue with warm water, and dry the item off. Test your item to make sure it really is made of brass by trying to stick a magnet on it. If the magnet sticks, you probably have something that is brass-plated. If it doesn’t stick, you’re working with pure brass. Use a little bit of olive oil to shine your brass item after you’ve cleaned and polished it. Just dab some onto a cloth and lightly rub it all over the brass. steps.headline: Mix white vinegar, salt, and flour to restore dirty or dull copper.
steps.description: Start by cleaning the item with warm, soapy water. After that is done, mix 1 teaspoon (5 grams) of white table salt, 2 to 3 tablespoons (30 to 44 mL) of white vinegar, and 1 tablespoon of flour (15 grams) to make a thick paste; spread the paste onto the copper item and let it sit for 20 to 30 minutes. Polish the copper with a lint-free towel, rinse away the residue, and dry the item off. For small, grooved sections, use a clean toothbrush or something similar to clean those hard-to-reach areas. Lemon juice can also be used to clean copper—just slice a lemon in half, dip the exposed part in salt, and then rub it on the copper item. This works great in the kitchen for copper pots and pans.

steps.headline: Restore tarnished silver with baking soda and water.
steps.description: Wash your silver with soapy water. Then, line a pot with aluminum foil and fill it with 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of water. Add 2 to 3 tablespoons (30 to 45 grams) of baking soda to the water and bring the water to a boil. Put your silver into the water and let it boil until the foil turns black. Remove the items with tongs and dry them off with a lint-free towel. For extremely tarnished pieces, you may need to treat them 2 to 3 times before they really come clean. You can, of course, use silver polish; just keep in mind that some brands can be pretty toxic, so use gloves when cleaning with it and work in a well-ventilated area.

steps.headline: Soak your gold in warm soapy water to remove dirt and grime.
steps.description: Mix together 2 to 3 drops of dish soap with warm water. Stir them together until the water is sudsy. Soak your gold jewelry in the water for 15 to 30 minutes, then use a soft, clean brush to dislodge any dirt or grime. Rinse the gold off under water, then buff it with a lint-free cloth. When you’re rinsing your gold jewelry under water, use a colander to ensure you don’t accidentally lose something down the drain. There are also cleaning products made specifically for gold jewelry that you can buy from the store.

steps.headline: Maintain your chrome’s shine with soap, water, and vinegar.
steps.description: Use a clean cloth and soapy water to clean your basic chrome items, like faucets, handles, and pots. For harder to remove stains, use a clean cloth and white vinegar or apple cider vinegar to rub the chrome clean. Dry the item off thoroughly so it doesn’t develop any water spots. For car parts, you may also want to add wax to the chrome so that it shines and stays clean for longer.Tip: To remove rust from chrome, try dipping a crumpled piece of aluminum foil in vinegar, then scrub the rusted section with the foil.

steps.headline: Use hot water or a baking soda paste to clean stainless steel.
steps.description: Use a lint-free cloth and hot water to wipe down stainless steel appliances and kitchen gadgets. Dry off the cleaned item with a dry lint-free cloth. For stubborn stains, make a paste out of baking soda and water, rub it into the stainless steel, then rinse away the paste with hot water. There are also wipes you can buy at the store that are made specifically for stainless steel. If you have a stainless steel stove, toaster, or other appliance, these can be a really convenient investment.

steps.headline: Use a grinder or sander to work the rust off of a metal object.
steps.description: This is a great chemical-free option, but keep in mind that the grinding or sanding motion will also remove any paint or finish that’s on the metal. Follow your tool’s operating instructions to strip away rust from any metal object. Don’t bear down on the item in any one place for too long, as that could deteriorate the metal—instead, keep the grinder or sander moving at all times and check your progress often. In general, use the coarsest abrasive to start out removing the rust, then change it out for a finer grit to make sure the item is smooth instead of ragged when you finish.

steps.headline: Apply an acid-based remover to dissolve rust.
steps.description: This is a great option if you don’t have power tools but still need to deal with a metal item that has started to rust. Purchase an acid-based remover from your home improvement store or online, and follow its instructions carefully. In general, you’ll submerge the rusted item into the liquid remover and leave it for a few hours or even overnight. Scrape away the dissolved rust and repeat the process as many times as you need to clean away all the rust. If you’re working with an item that is too big to submerge, use a paintbrush to apply the acid-based remover to the rusted area. Warning: Always work in a well-ventilated space and wear rubber gloves and goggles when working with chemical cleaners.

steps.headline: Opt for a chemical-free solvent for a gentler cleaning process.
steps.description: Check out your local home improvement store to see what kinds of chemical-free rust removers they have available (or, shop online if your local store doesn’t carry one). Soak the rusted item in the solvent and leave it alone for as long as the instructions indicate. After the time is up, use a sponge or paper towel to wipe away the dissolved rust, and repeat the process another 2 to 3 times if it’s needed. Generally, using a chemical-free solvent will take a lot more time than using an acid-based remover. Also, most of these cleaners can’t be sprayed or painted onto an item, so you’ll need enough solvent to completely submerge whatever you need to clean.

steps.headline: Brush on a rust converter to remove rust and prime the object.
steps.description: Choose either a spray or a liquid converter, both of which can be found at your local home improvement store. Apply liquid converter with a paintbrush; spray the aerosol version onto the rusted item. Follow the instructions and let the converter rest on the rusted area for as long as it needs. Once it is dry, you’re ready to move on with the rest of your project. The converter kills rust, and in the process, it also preps the item to have a new coat of paint applied. If you don’t want to paint the item, apply a second coat of the converter to protect the item from developing rust again in the future. Use a disposable paintbrush to apply the liquid converter—you won’t be able to reuse the brush without contaminating whatever it is you planned to put it into.

steps.headline: Prevent rust by priming metal before you paint it.
steps.description: In addition to keeping your metal items in safe places and away from moisture, you can also prime and paint metal objects to keep them safe from rust (think about your car—when the paint chips, that area quickly becomes susceptible to rust). Use a primer on a metal object, like certain types of outdoor furniture, and then apply an even layer of paint on top of the primer to really seal the metal. If you aren’t going to paint the item, you can still use primer and then spray on a clear, glossy topcoat overtop of it to protect the metal.
